[script://<cmd>]
interval = [<decimal>|<cron schedule>]
* The special value "0" forces this scripted input to be run continuously. As soon as the script exits, the input restarts it. 
* The special value "-1" causes the scripted input to run once on start-up. 
* NOTE: when you specify a cron schedule, the input does not run the script on start-up. 
* Default: 60.0

Selected Answer: C

Splunk documentation explains the following: 
"The "interval" setting is used to specify how often the scripted input runs, either in seconds or using a cron schedule. In this case, the script "myscript.sh" is set to run continuously, with an interval of 0 seconds. This means that as soon as the script exits, it will be restarted by the Splunk system, resulting in it running continuously."

questions.question_text:
What will the following inputs.conf stanza do?

[script://myscript.sh]
interval=0

choices.A: The script will run at the default interval of 60 seconds.
choices.B: The script will be run only once for each time Splunk is restarted.
choices.C: The script will be run. As soon as the script exits, Splunk restarts it.
choices.D: The script will not be run.

questions.question_text: Load balancing on a Universal Forwarder is not scaling correctly. The forwarder’s outputs.conf and the tcpout stanza are setup correctly. What else could be the cause of this scaling issue? (Choose all that apply.)

choices.B: The DNS record used is not setup with a valid list of IP addresses.
choices.D: The receiving port is not properly setup to listen on the right port.
choices.C: The inputs.conf’s _SYSLOG_ROUTING is not setup to use the right group names.
choices.A: The indexAndForward value is not set properly.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
if indexAndForward is not set properly, it can affect how data is distributed and load balanced across the forwarders. indexAndForward is used in the configuration of Splunk forwaders, specically in the outputs.conf
but since the outputs.conf is set up correctly, this eliminate A. 

if the DNS record that the Universal Forwarder relies on does not have the correct list of IP addresses for the indexers, the load balancing would fail to distribute data correctly .

if ther recieving port is not corretly configured, it can cause issues with data transmission and load balancing 

the inputs.conf's _SYSLOG_ROUGHING is used for directing syslog events to specified groups, but it does not impact the load balancing of data forwarded by a Universal Forwarder.

the answer is BD

Selected Answer: BD
The correct answers to this question are:

B. The DNS record used is not setup with a valid list of IP addresses.
D. The receiving port is not properly setup to listen on the right port.

A. /var/log/host_469386086/bar/file/foo.txt

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.2.1/Admin/Inputsconf

"..." searches recursively through one or more directories. This means that /foo/.../bar matches foo/1/bar, foo/1/2/bar, etc.

The asterisk (*) matches anything in a single path segment; unlike "...", it does not search recursively. 

For example, /foo/*/bar matches the files /foo/1/bar, /foo/2/bar, etc. However, it does not match /foo/bar or /foo/1/2/bar.

Selected Answer: B
This has to by a typo, both A and B are absolutely, 100% correct.

Selected Answer: A
/var/log -- root directory
*/ bar -- any subdirectory just before /bar (this eliminate C and D)
.../ -- any further subdirectories within /bar (this eliminated B)
*.txt -- only .txt files

The correct file that will be matched for the given monitor stanza [monitor:///var/log/*/bar/.../*.txt] is:

B. /var/log/host_469336086/bar/foo.txt

Explanation: The wildcard * matches any string, and the ... allows for any directories to be included in the path. However, the path must end in .txt due to the /*.txt specification. Option B fits this pattern as it directly falls under a bar directory and ends with .txt.

A non-clustered Splunk environment has three indexers (A,B,C) and two search heads (X,Y). During a search executed on search head X, indexer A crashes. What is Splunk’s response?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Splunk does not re-attempt searches on its own and changing the SH makes no sense if the Idx has not been recovered.

choices.D: Repeat the search request on indexer B without informing the user.
choices.C: Update the user in Splunk web that their results may be incomple and that Splunk will try to re-execute the search.
choices.B: Update the user in Splunk web informing them that the results of their search may be incomplete.
choices.A: Inform the user in Splunk web that their results may be incomplete and have them attempt the search from search head Y.
